title: John Cross opinion: "Liverpool have not just dropped out of the title race but also out of the top four"
text:
Sport Opinion Klopp has a battle on his hands to stay in the top four (Photo: Leicester City FC) Share Get Liverpool   Thank you for subscribing!   
Jurgen Klopp watched from the touchline, probably trying to work out which team was supposed to be in crisis. 
Liverpool were so good in their last game, when they took Tottenham apart, that it was easy to forget how bad their results have been since the turn of the year. 
That victory over Tottenham is their only Premier League win of 2017 and Liverpool have not just dropped out of the title race but also out of the top four. 
Maybe it is partly Klopp’s fault because they were so good in the first half of the season that it gave Liverpool false hope and expectation. Klopp looks very grumpy on the King Power Stadium touchline (Photo: Leicester City FC) The German was not his usual jovial self as his side lost again (Photo: Liverpool FC) Vardy puts the Foxes into a three goal lead (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
Let’s be realistic. Liverpool are still very much a work in progress and finishing in the top four would be a good achievement. 
But what is harder to understand is why Liverpool’s form has been so unpredictable and inconsistent this season. 
They did not just beat Tottenham, they destroyed them with a fabulous all-action display and then went on a mid-season break to La Manga. 
If that was supposed to recharge Liverpool’s batteries and reinvigorate the players, then it did no such thing at the King Power Stadium. 
They were outfought and outmanoeuvred from the start, Leicester overwhelming them in midfield as Liverpool missed injured captain Jordan Henderson’s drive, energy and leadership. Danny Drinkwater smashes in a wonder strike (Photo: REUTERS) Klopp grew more and more frustrated on the side lines (Photo: Liverpool FC) 
Liverpool’s defence looked shaky with Lucas Leiva alongside Joel Matip and they struggled against Jamie Vardy’s pace and runs. 
Liverpool rarely found any sort of rhythm and momentum going forward. Their squad suddenly looks painfully thin. Philippe Coutinho producing a rare moment of quality with a brilliant consolation. 
No wonder Klopp often looked furious on the touchline, anger and frustration all over his face as he saw his Liverpool players get caught up in the Leicester soap opera. 
When Vardy headed in his second goal and Leicester’s third, Klopp looked as bemused as the rest of us. Where has this Leicester team been hiding? Meanwhile, Klopp must be wondering when the real Liverpool will stand up. poll loading Should Liverpool sack Jurgen Klopp? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
